snippet: The cost of New York City’s special education prekindergarten program has nearly doubled in six years, and governmental oversight of the contractors running it has often been lax.
abstract: Analysis shows that New York City is paying private contractors more than $1 billion in 2012 to operate a little-known special education program for 3- and 4-year-olds, nearly double the amount it paid six years before; although the number of children in the program has risen slowly, annual costs have soared; interviews with city officials and experts reveal that the program is far more costly than it is in other areas, and oversight by the city and state has been lax.
lead_paragraph: The cost of New York City’s special education prekindergarten program has nearly doubled in six years, and governmental oversight of the contractors running it has often been lax.

headline.seo: Prekindergarten Costs in New York City Have Doubled in 6 Years
headline.main: Cost of Prekindergarten Special Education Is Soaring
headline.print_headline: For City, Costs Are Mounting In Pre-K Effort
